folder: Varick Street & Houston Street (West), Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
207, 209 Varick Street and 244 West Houston Street, at and ad- joining the N.W. corner.
About 1900.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

(2)
The same, also including 211 Varick Street and 246 West Houston Street.
About 1910.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

folder: Downing Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
69 Downing Street, adjoining the N.E. corner of Varick Street, showing the lower floors of a 2½-story structure. The structures to the left were demolished in 1915 when Varick Street was widened.

About 1914.

folder: Varick Street & Houston Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
207 to 225 Varick Street, west side, from Houston (formerly Hammersley Street) to Clarkson Streets. All of these old houses, except Nos. 223, 225, the two at the Clarkson Street end of the block, are frame buildings faced with brick. They are shortly to be demolished to make room for the Maltz Building.
June, 1925.

folder: Houston Street (West & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Houston Street, western section (formerly Hammersley Street), west of, adjoining, and at Varick Street, view northeast. In the foreground, on the south side, excavation for the future United States Appraisers Stores Building is going on. On the north side may be seen the eastern wing, 250 West Houston Street, of Public School No. 95, and the south side of the new Maltz Building, which replaced 248-242 West Houston Street and 207 to 225 Varick Street, the entire west side of the northernmost block. December 7, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Downing Street & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Downing Street, northeast from and including Varick Street. The southwestern corner of the old Herring Farm, within which lies all but the westernmost few feet of Downing Street, is just off the picture to the right, the observer is standing in the former Trinity Church Farm. Downing Street is the first of seven streets laid out in the Herring Farm at right angles to Bedford and Herring (now Bleecker) Streets.
The tall building on the horizon, seen down Downing Street, is the One Fifth Avenue apartment hotel; a little to the right of it the tower of the brand new Consolidated Gas Building, on East 14th Street, can be discerned.

September 1, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Houston Street (West & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)
Stables of 214-216-218 West Houston Street, north side, east of Varick Street. These stables are in the rear of the three houses to which they belong, with a little cobble-stoned court-yard in between. The dark body at the left is the rear of No. 214; and the view is west. June 23, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
Stables of 216-214 West Houston Street and the rear of No. 214 itself. The view is east, showing the stables at the left. June 23, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
A detail of the stable belonging to No. 216, the middle house. June 23, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

folder: Houston Street (West & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
(1)

218-216-214 West Houston Street, north side, east of Varick Street: three houses dating back to the time of the Civil War, but not much earlier. No. 216 has a passageway through it from the street to the stables, which are in the rear. The building adjoining them at the right is No. 206, as if these three houses were numbered 218, 212, 208, respectively.
June 15, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

A detail of 218-216-214 West Houston Street, the driveway through No. 216, from the street to the stables in the rear of the building. Compare 48-50 King Street, just east of the S.E. corner of Varick Street.
June 23, 1930.

(Picture fastened in mounting)

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Houston Street (West & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
222 to 200 West Houston Street (western section, formerly Hammersley Street), north side, east of and from Varick Street. The roofs of Nos. 58-46 Downing Street, on the south side of Downing, are shown at the left.
In the left foreground of the picture we are looking down on the old Hammersley Iron Foundry, originally 51-53 Hammersley Street and 60 Downing Street; it extends through the block. The Houston Street wing has been cut down from three-stories to one-story, and the building made over into a garage.
The old boundary line between the Trinity Church Farm and the Herring Farm runs along the backs of the Houston Street houses, dividing the block. The Downing Street part of it, west to and including No. 66 Downing Street, is all inside the old Herring Farm.
June 23, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Houston Street (West & Varick Street, Manhattan, NY
text:
Houston Street, western section (formerly Hammersley Street), north side, east from and including Varick Street. The one-story garage with the sign "Brakes," at 224-226 West Houston, is very new, less than three years old as shown, replacing the old three-story wagon shop which was once the Hammersley Iron Foundry. The corner building, 206 Varick Street, was built since 1922, replacing two frame houses, 230-232 West Houston Street. May 19, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

folder: Varick Street & Houston Street (West), Manhattan, NY
text:
Varick Street, east side, north from West Houston (right) to Downing (left) Streets. Also shown is West Houston Street, at, adjoining and east of the N.E. corner of Varick Street.

May 29, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.
